awd_titl_txt: FET: Small: Collaborative Research: Integrated Spintronic Synapses and Neurons for Neuromorphic Computing Circuits - I(SNC)^2
awd_abstract_narration:
There are many pressing problems today where data-intensive tasks are needed to be accomplished in real time. This can range from sequencing DNA, to self-driving cars recognizing a person walking by, to predicting the trajectory of a flying object. In these examples, traditional computing faces a performance wall where the computing time and energy is severely limited by memory access. If computers could be built closer to the way the brain computes, where memory and computation are densely connected together like the neurons (and synapses) of the brain, these tasks could be performed with a million times less energy. This requires doing research on designing and building artificial neurons and synapses, and research on connecting them together into neuromorphic circuits. Due to the many different kinds of problems this new type of computing will address, research in this area will have impact not only in the semiconductor industry, but also far-reaching impact in medicine, defense, and new technologies. This project will educate and train multiple Ph.D.-level and undergraduate students in this interdisciplinary field, with skills highly sought after in academia, national labs, and industry. It will also have significance for broadening participation of women and under-represented minorities in computing: the researchers seek to educate and train women and Hispanic students from their state of Texas.

Nanodevices made from magnetic materials (such as iron) have many properties that make them uniquely suitable as artificial neurons and synapses to enable such computing. Nevertheless, a number of technical problems remain in using magnetic devices for neuromorphic computing, which this project aims to address: there has been little experimental study of circuits that combine spintronic neurons and synapses, the devices and circuits designed so far do not capture all the desired biological behaviors, and there have been no circuits designed that operate without external silicon-based devices. This interdisciplinary collaborative effort between experiment and circuit design will address these challenges by building and studying circuits using three-terminal magnetic tunnel junction devices. The research will result in design and fabrication of new types of these magnetic devices that more accurately represent the brain's functions, and in measurements of the magnetic devices' behavior in circuits. The project has the potential to establish magnetic materials as a platform for neuromorphic computing, similar to how silicon is the platform material for traditional computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was centered on integrated neuromorphic circuits comprising spintronic synapses and neurons that mimic neurobiological functionality and structure. Neuromorphic computing is the computing of the future, where our computers will closely mimic how the biological mammalian brain computes. Magnetic materials and devices are promising candidates for such a computer, since they can provide synapse-like and neuron-like functionality while having high endurance and compatibility with silicon-based computers. But, effort needs to be undertaken to make this idea a reality, both at the device level and at the circuit integration level.

In this project, we focused on a particular type of magnetic neuromorphic device, the domain wall-magnetic tunnel junction (DW-MTJ). In this device, the motion of a magnetic domain wall under a tunnel barrier modulates the resistance across the tunnel barrier. We used these devices for synapses in which the domain wall position represents a synaptic weight, as well as for neurons in which the integration of an input signal through domain wall motion (with a leaking force) causes the neuron to fire. We have shown that the interconnection of these DW-MTJ synapses and neurons enables CMOS-free integrated spintronic neuromorphic computing circuits.

In the design portion of this project, we proposed a novel neuron structure, modeled the synapse and neurons, designed integrated spintronic perceptron circuits, and provided guidance for the experimental portion of the project. The novel neuron is a four-terminal DW-MTJ that enables the direct connectivity of multi-layer perceptron networks, as well as feedback to enable learning. The various DW-MTJ synapses and neurons were modeled using simplifications of the micromagnetic behavior as well as by leveraging analogies to classical mechanics, permitting rapid and accurate simulations of large-scale spintronic neuromorphic networks that incorporate device variations. These models were used to design integrated CMOS-free multi-layer neuromorphic networks with DW-MTJ synapses and neurons, and to demonstrate their feasibility. In addition to performing inference with pre-trained networks, we designed circuits that cause online learning rules to emerge from the direct feedback connectivity through four-terminal DW-MTJs within the network. Furthermore, throughout this project, the design and experimental research was tightly coupled to ensure effectiveness and practicality.

In the experimental portion of this project, we implemented the designed neuromorphic devices and studied their behavior. We fabricated and measured controllable synaptic weights in the DW-MTJs. To our knowledge, this is the first time multi-weight magnetic synapses have been shown that are scalable and concatenable into fully spintronic circuits. We dedicated effort to understanding and characterizing the DW-MTJ synapse, as well as taking the experimental device data and inputting it into neural network models to show the benefits for neuromorphic computing. Some main findings include that the DW-MTJ synapse has stable resistance levels over numerous cycles, and we show this makes the synapse a good candidate for inference tasks. We also show that this stability makes up for the relatively small on/off ratio of MTJs compared to other synapse technology options. We also show the shape of the DW-MTJ synapse determines how stochastic vs. deterministic the setting of the resistance levels is, and we show this is useful for learning tasks. We also fabricated and measured DW-MTJ neurons and showed they can function as stochastic neurons, where the switching probability of the DW across the MTJ depends on the voltage amplitude of input spikes. The estimated energy per operation is measured and is competitive with digital SRAM implementations of spiking neurons at greatly reduced area and without standby energy dissipation from leakage current. We use the experimental data to simulate spiking neural networks processing noisy datasets, and we showed the stochastic DW-MTJ devices retain accuracy at higher noise levels.

Taken together, these results have impacted the discipline of electrical and computer engineering to build new computers that can accomplish data-intensive tasks in real time. We leverage the advanced physics in the devices to implement neuron and synapses functions that can more energy-efficiently do such tasks, and we design and demonstrate integrated circuits in which these spintronic devices are cascaded and integrated in a CMOS-free multi-layer neural network crossbar structure. This improved understanding of neuromorphic computing systems that efficiently emulate biological information processing has broad impacts in all areas of big data, from self-driving cars to DNA sequencing.

This project has also trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students, increasing the US workforce in microelectronics. For example, one graduate student received her Ph.D. in May 2022 and is now working at Samsung Austin. Two of the undergraduate students on the project received NSF Graduate Research Fellowships and are now in graduate school. The project has also impacted K-12 education through our efforts to integrate the research into K-12 teacher training. The project also increased diversity in electrical engineering; e.g., through the PIs? time hosting the Rising Stars program for women in ECE interested in academic careers.
